page.title: 03ECOLOGY
page.content: The woodland tree species are mixed, some the result of mans influence. There is not much evidence of current woodland management. Beech and oak are common with some silver birch and hazel which may have been coppiced in the past. Braken, holly and gorse are common lower storey plants especially where the woodland opens into Keston common. The ground layer plants include a great variety of grasses, herbs and wild flowers especially along the edge of the woodlands and field boundaries. common species - white & red campion, trefoils, daises, buttercups, hogweed, pantains, & labiates. The agricultural land is mainly small fields with many hedgerows providing an ideal habitat for wild flowers, small trees and birdlife. Poppies growing among the cereals suggest a poor level of management.
